unit_designation: 1re Division Française Libre (1st Free French Division)

commander.name: Général de Division Diego Brosset
commander.previous_service: Succeeded Edgard de Larminat after Tunisia Campaign, Commander of 1st Free French Brigade

supply_logistics.supply_status: Good - 1st Free French Division post-Tunisia Campaign (May-June 1943) resting and refitting in Tripolitania under British Eighth Army. Supplied via British logistics with fuel reserves 8 days for motorized operations, ammunition excellent at 21 days for sustained operations, water 5L/man/day (79,000L total / 15,800 personnel), food reserves 28 days. Division received replacement equipment and personnel after Tunisia. Commander Général Diego Brosset assumed command May 1943. Division preparing for Italian campaign (Sicily/Italy). Supply base: British Eighth Army depots in Libya.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Libyan coastal plain - post-campaign rest area in Tripolitania, good roads, desert terrain, coastal access

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 1re Brigade Française Libre (1st Free French Brigade)
subordinate_units.notes: Includes 13th DBLE (Demi-Brigade of Foreign Legion), Bataillon du Pacifique (Pacific Battalion), Bataillon de Nouvelle-Calédonie (New Caledonia Battalion), 22nd North African Battalion

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 2e Brigade Française Libre (2nd Free French Brigade)
subordinate_units.notes: Includes 1st, 3rd, 11th March Battalions, 1st Foreign Legion Battalion

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 4e Brigade Française Libre (4th Free French Brigade)
subordinate_units.notes: Formed from units arriving from various Free French garrisons, reinforced after Tunisia

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 1er Régiment de Marche de Spahis Marocains

subordinate_units.notes: Two motorized 75mm battalions, equipped primarily with British 25-pounders
Engineers, signals (1st Signal Battalion with 2 companies), medical, supply, transport companies

tactical_doctrine.role: Motorized infantry division organized on British brigade model, post-Tunisia Campaign rest and refit period
special_capabilities: Veteran desert warfare force with Tunisia Campaign experience including Battle of Takrouna
Multi-ethnic composition including Free French, Foreign Legion, Colonial troops, Pacific Islanders
Proficient in mobile desert operations with British equipment and doctrine
Strong morale from Tunisia victory, preparing for Italian campaign
tactical_innovations: Consolidated Free French forces from multiple theaters into cohesive division
Effective integration of diverse national and colonial units under unified French command
Adapted to British tactical doctrine while maintaining French military traditions and élan
known_issues: Mixed equipment from French, British, and American sources requiring complex logistics
Some units still equipped with obsolescent French weapons pending replacement
Integration of new replacements after Tunisia casualties
Limited heavy armor compared to British armored divisions
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive experience in desert operations from Libyan, Saharan, and Tunisia campaigns; excellent water discipline; adapted to extreme heat and supply constraints; veteran force ready for Mediterranean operations

special_rules: Veteran Desert Fighters: +1 to combat rolls in desert terrain
Tunisia Veterans: Re-roll one failed combat roll per battle (Battle of Takrouna experience)
Multinational Force: Mixed command structure may cause coordination delays
Free French Determination: Re-roll failed morale checks once per battle
British Equipment: Uses British supply rules and logistics
historical_engagements: Battle of Takrouna (April 1943) - Famous assault where 1st FFL captured strategic height

source: Nafziger Collection 943fhaa.pdf: French Gaulist Forces 12 August 1943 - 1st French Division structure in Libya/Egypt post-Tunisia, brigade composition, artillery (Tier 1, 92% confidence)
Playfair, History of the Second World War: Mediterranean and Middle East Vol.IV - 1st Free French Division Tunisia Campaign, Diego Brosset command succession May 1943 (Tier 1, 90% confidence)
Chemins de mémoire (French Ministry of Defence): Diego Brosset biography, command of 1st FFL Division May 1943-Sept 1944, brigade commanders (Tier 2, 85% confidence)
Ordre de la Libération museum archives: 1st FFL Division post-Tunisia organization, Battle of Takrouna April 1943, rest period May-June 1943 (Tier 2, 83% confidence)
Service Historique de la Défense: 1re DFL organization charts Q2 1943, British equipment allocations, casualty replacements (Tier 2, 82% confidence)
Wikipedia: 1st Free French Division - Diego Brosset command, Tunisia operations, preparation for Italian campaign (Tier 2, 78% confidence)
Cross-referenced: Diego Brosset assumed command May 15, 1943 (approximate), succeeding Edgard de Larminat
Cross-referenced: Division formed 1 February 1943, fought Tunisia Campaign March-May 1943
Cross-referenced: Battle of Takrouna (19-20 April 1943) - major action in Tunisia Campaign
Cross-referenced: Brigade commanders - Pierre Koenig (1st BFL), Henri Cazaud (2nd BFL) continued from Q1
Calculated: Personnel 15,800 from brigade strengths (1st BFL 5,200 + 2nd BFL 4,900 + 4th BFL 3,300 + support 2,400), increased from Q1 due to replacements
British Eighth Army organization tables: Free French equipment post-Tunisia (Valentine, Stuart tanks, 25-pdr artillery, British trucks)
Schema v3.1.0: supply_logistics and weather_environment with post-Tunisia rest period conditions
known_gaps: Exact date of Diego Brosset's command assumption estimated as mid-May 1943
Some subordinate unit commanders not identified by name in Nafziger sources
Vehicle counts estimated from British supply patterns for motorized divisions in Mediterranean theater
4th Brigade composition and commander details remain sparse
Exact equipment losses from Tunisia Campaign and replacement schedules not fully documented
notes: Diego Brosset succeeded Edgard de Larminat as division commander in May 1943 after Tunisia Campaign
Division remained organized under British model with three brigades instead of traditional French regimental structure
Equipped primarily with British weapons and vehicles, with some French legacy equipment
Division in rest and refit period May-June 1943 in Tripolitania, Libya after Tunisia victory
Division redesignated as 1re Division Motorisée d'Infanterie (1st DMI) on 1 August 1943
Personnel estimate of 15,800 includes replacements received after Tunisia casualties (up from 15,200 in Q1)
Nafziger source dated 12 August 1943 provides authoritative structure for Q2 period
Division preparing for Italian campaign (Sicily invasion July 1943, Italy September 1943)
